cluster_relations.rel_desc: Female butterflies use specific host plants as sites to lay their eggs.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Butterfly Life Cycle Organisms and Host Plants
remarks: Relation name chosen to emphasize oviposition usage.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Fluid is pumped into the butterfly wings to make them expand and harden.
Nectar is produced by or obtained from flowers.
Adult butterflies visit flowers to obtain nectar.
remarks: Relation inferred; not stated with an explicit verb like 'visit'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Pollen is moved between flowers during pollination.
The adult butterfly stage is a stage within the butterfly life cycle.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: fourth and final stage (per entity descriptions)

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The butterfly life cycle includes the egg stage as its initial phase.
The butterfly life cycle is one of the intricate processes that make up the natural world.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: within ecosystems of the natural world
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: EducationalContext: understanding this life cycle deepens appreciation of the natural world

remarks: Relation used to encode that the life cycle is considered one of the natural world's processes.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism uses the object (typically a plant or substrate) as a site for laying eggs (oviposition).
args.justification: The description specifies that female butterflies use specific host plants as the sites where they lay eggs, which is best captured as using the object as an oviposition site.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject fluid fills the internal structure or cavity of the object, typically to enable its expansion or functional development.
args.justification: The instance describes fluid being pumped into butterfly wings, effectively filling them to allow expansion and hardening; a simple, reusable predicate 'fills' matches this.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject substance is produced by the object organism or structure as its biological source.
args.justification: Nectar originates from and is produced by flowers; a directional source predicate 'is_produced_by' cleanly captures that the subject (nectar) has the object (flowers) as its biological producer.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism visits the object (e.g., a flower) specifically to obtain food resources.
args.justification: The description emphasizes adult butterflies going to flowers to obtain nectar; this is a visit driven by feeding, so a more specific predicate 'visits_for_feeding' is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject material is transported or moved between instances of the object category.
args.justification: Pollen is described as being moved between flowers during pollination; this is a transfer of the subject (pollen) between multiple objects (flowers), best captured as 'is_transferred_between'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject represents a distinct stage within the life cycle process denoted by the object.
args.justification: The adult butterfly stage is explicitly a stage within the butterfly life cycle, so a directional predicate from stage to life cycle 'is_life_cycle_stage_of' is precise and reusable.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject life cycle process includes the object as one of its distinct stages.
args.justification: Here the butterfly life cycle has the egg stage as an included stage; the inverse view of the previous relation is needed, so 'includes_life_cycle_stage' from life cycle to stage is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject is a constituent element, process, or component within the broader system or whole denoted by the object.
args.justification: The butterfly life cycle is described as one of the processes that make up the natural world, which is a standard part–whole relation; 'is_part_of' is the conventional predicate for that.
Using host plants as oviposition sites is a reproductive behavior of the butterfly, linking organism behavior to reproductive resources.
Fluid filling the wings is part of post-emergence wing development and morphological change, so it fits a developmental morphology class.
Nectar being produced by flowers is a classic case of a biological structure producing a resource; grouping under biological production is appropriate.
Adult butterflies visiting flowers to obtain nectar is a feeding/foraging behavior linking consumer to resource locations.
Pollen movement between flowers during pollination is a transfer of reproductive material integral to pollination ecology.
Both relations connect life cycle stages and the overall life cycle (stage-to-cycle and cycle-to-stage), forming a coherent family of life cycle stage relations.
The butterfly life cycle is modeled as one of many processes within the natural world, which is an ecological part–whole (component–system) relation.
Both relations describe butterflies using plant structures (host plants or flowers) as resources or sites for specific purposes (oviposition and feeding), fitting a usage dimension.
The fluid filling the wings changes their state (expansion and hardening), which is best categorized as a structural/state modification process.
The relation encodes that flowers are the causal biological source that produces nectar; this is a cause–effect style production relation.
Pollen is moved between spatially distinct flowers; the core semantics involve transfer across locations within a pollination context.
Life cycle stages (egg, adult, etc.) are temporally ordered phases within the butterfly life cycle; these relations primarily reflect temporal staging.
Modeling the butterfly life cycle as one of many processes that make up the natural world is a part–whole / composition relation at an ecological scale.

executed_decisions.justification: The butterfly life cycle is described as one of the processes that make up the natural world, which is a standard part–whole relation; 'is_part_of' is the conventional predicate for that.

The fluid filling the wings changes their state (expansion and hardening), which is best categorized as a structural/state modification process.
The relation encodes that flowers are the causal biological source that produces nectar; this is a cause–effect style production relation.
